title: AB 2466
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 2101 of the Elections Code in California is amended to specify that a person eligible to register to vote must be a US citizen, a California resident, not currently in prison or on parole for a felony conviction, and at least 18 years old at the time of the next election. The definitions of "imprisoned" and "parole" are provided in the section. Section 2101 of the Elections Code in California outlines the eligibility criteria for voter registration, including being a US citizen, a California resident, not imprisoned or on parole for a felony, and at least 18 years old. Additionally, individuals as young as 16 can preregister to vote. The definitions of "imprisoned" and "parole" are provided in the section. A county program to encourage voter registration must include a statement specifying eligibility criteria: US citizenship, California residency, not being in prison or on parole for a felony, and being at least 18 years old. This amends Section 2106 of the Elections Code. A county program to promote voter registration must include a statement outlining eligibility requirements: US citizenship, California residency, not being in prison or on parole for a felony, and being at least 18 years old. This amends Section 2106 of the Elections Code. A county program promoting voter registration must include a statement with eligibility requirements: US citizenship, California residency, not in prison or on parole for a felony, and at least 18 years old. This amends Section 2106 of the Elections Code. Section 2106 of the Elections Code is amended to include eligibility requirements for voter registration programs, such as US citizenship, California residency, not being in prison or on parole for a felony, and being at least 18 years old. The clerk of the superior court provides the county elections official with a list of individuals convicted of a felony and committed to state prison. The elections official cancels the registration of those currently imprisoned or on parole for a felony. This process is done twice a year in April and September. The clerk of the superior court provides the Secretary of State and county elections official with a monthly statement of individuals committed to state prison for a felony. The officials cancel the registration of those currently imprisoned or on parole. The Commission on State Mandates will provide reimbursement to local agencies and school districts for costs mandated by this act.
